page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on Artemisia

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of Lepidoptera that feed on ''Artemisia''}} '''''[[Artemisia (plant)|Artemisia]]''''' [[species]] (wormwoods, mugworts and sagebrushes) are used as food plants by the [[caterpillar]]s of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] (butterflies and moths), including:
==Monophagous== Species which feed exclusively on ''Artemisia'' - they are [[phagy|monophagous]]
* [[Bucculatricidae]] ** Several ''[[Bucculatrix]]'' leaf-miner species: *** ''[[Bucculatrix absinthii|B. absinthii]]'' *** ''[[Bucculatrix andalusica|B. andalusica]]'' *** ''[[Bucculatrix artemisiella|B. artemisiella]]'' *** ''[[Bucculatrix atagina|B. atagina]]'' – only on [[field wormwood]] (''A. campestris'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix benacicolella|B. benacicolella]]'' – only on ''[[Artemisia alba|A. alba]]'' *** ''[[Bucculatrix canariensis|B. canariensis]]'' – only on ''[[Artemisia canariensis|A. canariensis]]'' *** ''[[Bucculatrix diffusella|B. diffusella]]'' – only on [[sea wormwood]] (''A. maritima'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix herbalbella|B. herbalbella]]'' – only on [[white wormwood]] (''A. herba-alba'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix koebelella|B. koebelella]]'' – only on [[California sagebrush]] (''A. californica'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix laciniatella|B. laciniatella]]'' – only on Siberian wormwood (''[[Artemisia laciniata|A. laciniata]]'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix leptalea|B. leptalea]]'' – only on [[tarragon]] (''A. dranunculus'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix noltei|B. noltei]]'' – only on [[common wormwood]] (''A. vulgaris'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix pannonica|B. pannonica]]'' – only on sea wormwood (''A. maritima'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix ratisbonensis|B. ratisbonensis]]'' – only on field wormwood (''A. campestris'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix salutatoria|B. salutatoria]]'' – only on [[common sagebrush]] (''A. tridentata'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix seorsa|B. seorsa]]'' – only on common sagebrush (''A. tridentata'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix tridenticola|B. tridenticola]]'' – only on common sagebrush (''A. tridentata'') * [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: *** ''[[Coleophora absinthii|C. absinthii]]'' – only on [[absinth wormwood]] (''A. absinthium'') *** ''[[Coleophora amentastra|C. amentastra]]'' – only on ''[[Artemisia turanica|A. turanica]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora artemisicolella|C. artemisicolella]]'' – only on common wormwood (''A. vulgaris'') *** ''[[Coleophora artemisiella|C. artemisiella]]'' – only on sea wormwood (''A. maritima'') *** ''[[Coleophora directella|C. directella]]'' – only on field wormwood (''A. campestris'') *** ''[[Coleophora dubiella|C. dubiella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora granulatella|C. granulatella]]'' – only on field wormwood (''A. campestris'') *** ''[[Coleophora guttella|C. guttella]]'' – only on ''A. turanica'' *** ''[[Coleophora polynella|C. polynella]]'' – only on ''A. turanica'' *** ''[[Coleophora settarii|C. settarii]]'' – only on ''[[Artemisia crithmifolia|A. crithmifolia]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora solenella|C. solenella]]'' – only on field wormwood (''A. campestris'') *** ''[[Coleophora succursella|C. succursella]]'' – only on field wormwood (''A. campestris'') *** ''[[Coleophora yomogiella|C. yomogiella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora zhusani|C. zhusani]]'' – only on ''A. turanica'' * [[Noctuidae]] ** ''[[Schinia accessa]]'' (angle-lined flower moth) – only on common sagebrush (''A. tridentata'') ** ''[[Schinia cumatilis]]'' (silver-banded gem) – only on fringed sagebrush (''[[Artemisia frigida|A. frigida]]'') ** ''[[Schinia nuchalis]]'' (spotted clover moth) – on field wormwood (''A. campestris''), tarragon (''A. dracunculus'') and possibly others
==Polyphagous== Species which feed on ''Artemisia'' and other plants - they are [[phagy|polyphagous]]
* [[Bucculatricidae]] ** Several ''[[Bucculatrix]]'' leaf-miner species: *** ''[[Bucculatrix arnicella|B. arnicella]]'' – recorded on [[common sagebrush]] (''A. tridentata'') *** ''[[Bucculatrix fatigatella|B. fatigatella]]'' – recorded on [[field wormwood]] (''A. campestris'') * [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearer species: *** ''[[Coleophora albicella|C. albicella]]'' – recorded on ''[[Artemisia caerulescens|A. caerulescens]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora caelebipennella|C. caelebipennella]]'' – recorded on field wormwood (''A. campestris'') *** ''[[Coleophora ditella|C. ditella]]'' – recorded on field wormwood (''A. campestris'') *** ''[[Coleophora gardesanella|C. gardesanella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora kurokoi|C. kurokoi]]'' – recorded on [[Japanese mugwort]] (''A. princeps'') *** ''[[Coleophora trochilella|C. trochilella]]'' – recorded on [[common wormwood]] (''A. vulgaris'') *** ''[[Coleophora vibicigerella|C. vibicigerella]]'' * [[Crambidae]] ** ''[[Dolicharthria punctalis]]'' – recorded on common wormwood (''A. vulgaris'') * [[Gelechiidae]] ** ''[[Chionodes distinctella]]'' – recorded on field wormwood (''A. campestris'') * [[Geometridae]] ** ''[[Chloroclystis v-ata]]'' (The V-pug) – recorded on common wormwood (''A. vulgaris'') ** ''[[Eupithecia absinthiata]]'' (wormwood pug) ** ''[[Eupithecia centaureata]]'' (lime-speck pug) ** ''[[Eupithecia icterata]]'' (tawny speckled pug) ** ''[[Eupithecia subfuscata]]'' (grey pug) ** ''[[Eupithecia succenturiata]]'' (bordered pug) – recorded on common wormwood (''A. vulgaris'') ** ''[[Eupithecia vulgata]]'' (common pug) ** ''[[Hemithea aestivaria]]'' (common emerald) ** ''[[Odontopera bidentata]]'' (scalloped hazel) – recorded on common wormwood (''A. vulgaris'') * [[Noctuidae]] ** ''[[Agrotis exclamationis]]'' (heart and dart) ** ''[[Amphipyra tragopoginis]]'' (mouse moth) – recorded on common wormwood (''A. vulgaris'') ** ''[[Antitype chi]]'' (grey chi) – recorded on common wormwood (''A. vulgaris'') ** ''[[Naenia typica]]'' (Gothic)
==External links== *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Artemisia&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Artemisia''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 7 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Artemisia]] [[Category:Artemisia (genus)|.Lepidoptera]]

page.title: List of Ramsar sites in Chad

revision.comment: Typo fixing, replaced: meausres → measures (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2014}}
[[File:ISS-30 Lake Fitri, Chad.jpg|thumb|300px|Satellite image of Lake Fitri]] '''Ramsar sites in [[Chad]]''' refer to the six sites designated as [[Ramsar Convention|Ramsar]] Wetlands of International Importance in Chad. They cover an area of {{convert|124050.68|sqkm}}. They include Lac Fitri, Partie tchadienne du lac Tchad, Plaine de Massenya, Plaines d'inondation des Bahr Aouk et Salamat, and Réserve de faune de Binder-Léré.
==Lac Fitri== The [[Lake Fitri|Lac Fitri Ramsar Site]] measures {{convert|1950|sqkm}} in size and was established on 13 June 1990. The Lake Fitri expands substantially during the rainy season, varying from year to year. Swamps encircle the lake periphery over a length of 150 km. ''[[Echinochloa stagnina]]'', ''[[Vossia cuspidata]]'' and ''[[Nymphaea aquatica]]'' are the common vegetation types noted while ''[[Acacia nilotica]]'' and ''[[Mitragyna inermis]]'' grow in the flooded zone of the lake. The fringe land area around the lake has annual [[grass]]es and [[sedge]]. Also, as an [[Important Bird Area]] it has both breeding and non-breeding species. It is wintering ground for a large number of Palearctic waterbirds. The large number of bird species recorded here are ''[[Aythya nyroca]]'', ''[[Balearica pavonina]]'', ''[[Ardeola ralloides]]'', ''[[Platalea alba]]'', ''[[Dendrocygna bicolor]]'', ''[[Dendrocygna viduata]]'', ''[[Anas acuta]]'', and ''[[Anas querquedula]]''. It provides refuge during the drought season to Afrotropical species and elephants. It is also known as a productive fishing lake with an annual fish catch of 3,000 tonnes.<ref name=Bird>{{Cite web|url=http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/userfiles/file/IBAs/AfricaCntryPDFs/Chad.pdf|format=pdf|title=Important Bird Areas in Africa and associated islands – Chad|accessdate=16 October 2013|publisher=BirdLife International Organization}}</ref><ref name=Ramsar/><ref name=Lake>{{Cite web|url=http://www.protectedplanet.net/sites/Lac_Fitri_Wetland_Of_International_Importance_Ramsar_Convention|title= Lac Fitri Ramsar Site, Wetland of International|accessdate=18 October 2013|publisher= Protectedplanet.net}}</ref>
==Partie tchadienne du lac Tchad== {{multiple image |direction = horizontal |align = right |width = 200 |image1 = Lakechad mapfr.png |caption1 = Map of Lake Chad |image2 = LakeChadBolaerialphoto.jpg |caption2 = Lake Chad at Bol (1971) }} The [[Lake Chad|Partie tchadienne du lac Tchad Ramsar Site]] measures {{convert|16481.68|sqkm}} in size. It was established as a Ramsar Wetland site in 2001<ref name=Ramsar>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ramsar.org/cda/en/ramsar-pubs-notes-anno-chad/main/ramsar/1-30-168%5E16481_4000_0_|title=The Annotated Ramsar List: Chad|accessdate= Ramsar Organization}}</ref> It is part of the greater transboundary Lake Chad shared with Cameroon, Niger, and Nigeria. The Partie tchadienne du lac Tchad was established under a cooperative effort of the [[Government of Chad]], the [[Lake Chad Basin Commission]], the Ramsar Bureau, [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] (WWF), [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] (IUCN), the [[Global Environment Facility]] (GEF), the [[World Bank]], and the [[United Nations Development Programme]](UNDP). It covers the Chad part of Lake Chad bordering a cordon of dunes on the northeast called the "erg" while the southern limits of the lake consists of plains. It is a composite of "open waters, islets and [[sandbank]]s, [[polder]]s, [[oases]] and temporary and permanent "natron" or alkalai pools" covering all the four nations which share it. Apart from water birds, it has about 150 fish species; the [[Kouri Ox]] is an [[endemic]] and threatened species here. The lake's flows are regulated and it also helps inn replenishing ground water. It provides livelihood for 3 million fisher folk. Cattle, sheep and camel are also raised on its banks. Blue algae (''[[spirulina (dietary supplement)|spiruline]]'') is also an important product from the lake.<ref name=Lakes>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldlakes.org/shownews.asp?newsid=159|title= Substantial portion of Lake Chad named a Ramsar site (Chad)|date=14 January 2002|accessdate=20 October 2013|publisher=Worldlakes organization}}</ref>
==Plaine de Massenya== The [[Plaine de Massenya Ramsar Site]] measures {{convert|25260|sqkm}} in size. It was established on 17 October 2008 in southwestern regions of the [[Chad Basin]]. The Plaine de Massenya wetland consists of freshwater marshes, rivers, streams and creeks. It provides flood moderation, retains the sediment load, and helps in recharge of ground water. Apart from 366 species of birds, there are also wildlife faunal species of [[African elephant]], [[leopard]]s, [[Nile crocodile]] and many more. Fish species also are in abundance and they feed on the plant species ''[[Echinachloa]]'' that thrive in the lake. People living in the area sustain their livelihood by fishing, agriculture and rearing of livestock.<ref name=Ramsar/>
==Plaines d'inondation des Bahr Aouk et Salamat== The [[Plaines d'inondation des Bahr Aouk et Salamat Ramsar Site]] measures {{convert|49220|sqkm}} in size and is one of the world's largest Ramsar sites. It was established on 1 June 2006, and is situated in a natural depression bordering the [[Central Africa Republic]]. The Plaines d'inondation des Bahr Aouk et Salamat wetland, which also subsumes the Zakouma National Park, provides sustenance to the wildlife of the area. Migratory waterbirds are a common sight. Fauna reported are species of hippos, leopards, elephants and many kinds antelopes. It is an important habitat for fish breeding and the annual fish catch is reported to be 15,000 tonnes. The wetlands fauna is threatened by poaching and vegetation is subject to intense grazing and also forest fires which need to be suitably addressed through community participatory management and environmental education. In this context, [[Global Environment Facility|GEF]] has also launched a pilot project in the area.<ref name=Ramsar/> After the civil war which ravaged the area, the Zakouma National Park has been strengthened with induction of elephants, giraffes and lions with assistance from the [[European Union]].<ref name=Designate>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/may2006/2006-05-23-03.asp|title=Chad Designates Enormous Wetland Reserve|date=23 May 2006|accessdate=20 October 2013|publisher=Environment News Service}}</ref>
==Plaines d'inondation du Logone et les dépressions Toupouri== The [[Plaines d'inondation du Logone et les dépressions Toupouri Ramsar Site]] covers an area of {{convert|29789|sqkm}}. It was established on 14 November 2005 and is one of Africa's largest wetlands. The Plaines d'inondation du Logone et les dépressions Toupouri wetland has number of water bodies in the form of rivers, permanent and temporary ponds, flood plains and lakes. In this widely varying ecosystem, the flora consists of many species including the African [[Palmyra palm]] and the néré (''[[Parkia biglobosa]]'') which are in the threatened list. The avi fauna consists of Occidental Palearctic and Ethiopian migratory species such as the [[black crowned-crane]], [[spur-winged goose]] and [[whistling duck]]'. Fishing is year round vocation of the people who reside in the wetland. The threats faced in the wetland relate to poaching, overgrazing, forest fires, oil exploration and pesticide. The GEF, World Bank, UNDP and Lake Chad Basin Commission have launched a project for its management.<ref name=Ramsar/>
==Réserve de faune de Binder-Léré== [[Binder-Léré Faunal Reserve|Réserve de faune de Binder-Léré Ramsar Site]] covers an area of {{convert|1350|sqkm}}. It was established as Ramsar Wetland reserve on 14 November 2005 on the Chad-Cameroonian border in Mayo-Kebbi administrative region.<ref name=Parks>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parks.it/world/TD/Eindex.html|title= Parks, Reserves, and Other Protected Areas in Chad|accessdate=17 October 2013|publisher=Parks.it}}</ref><ref name=Search>{{Cite web|url=http://www.protectedplanet.net/search?country_id=42&q=Chad|title=Search for protected areas|work=Official Record Only|accessdate=17 October 2013|publisher= Protectedplanet.net}}</ref> The wetland consists of lakes, ephemeral and perennial streams, and marshes. The Gauthiot Waterfalls on the Gauthiot River acts as barrier for movement of fish species from the [[Niger River]], upstream into the Lake Chad. The local [[Moundang]] tribals hold this falls in veneration. The site hosts a number faunal species of manatee, crocodiles, hippos, and cheetahs which are in the endangered list. It is habitat for waterbirds and some of the species are ''[[Dendrocygna]]'' spp., ''[[Balearica pavonina]]'', ''[[Pelecanus rufescens]]'' and ''[[Plectropterus gambensis]]''. Fishing, agriculture, hunting and rearing of livestock are the vocations of the local people for sustenence.<ref name=Ramsar/>
==References== {{reflist|3}}
[[Category:Ramsar sites in Chad| ]] [[Category:Lists of Ramsar sites|Chad]] [[Category:Chad geography-related lists|Ramsar sites]]

{{Redirect|Japanese earthquake|the 11 March 2011 earthquake in the Tōhoku region|2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami}} [[File:EQs 1900-2016 Japan tsum.png|thumb|300px|Earthquakes M5.5+ around Japan (1900-2016)
M7.0-7.9=163 EQs, M8.0+=14 EQs.[[USGS]] [https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/search/ Earthquake Catalog Search]]] This is a '''list of earthquakes in Japan''' with either a magnitude greater than or equal to 7.0 or which caused significant damage or casualties. As indicated below, magnitude is measured on the [[Richter magnitude scale]] (''ML'') or the [[moment magnitude scale]] (''Mw''), or the [[surface wave magnitude| surface wave magnitude scale]] (''Ms'') for very old earthquakes. The present list is not exhaustive, and reliable and precise magnitude data is scarce for earthquakes that occurred prior to the development of modern measuring instruments. ==Geological background== [[File:Japan separation.png|thumb|270px|left|The islands comprising the [[Japanese Archipelago]] were separated from mainland Asia by [[back-arc spreading]]]] The islands of Japan are primarily the result of several large oceanic movements occurring over hundreds of millions of years from the mid-[[Silurian]] to the [[Pleistocene]] as a result of the [[subduction]] of the [[Philippine Sea Plate]] beneath the continental [[Amurian Plate]] and [[Okinawa Plate]] to the south, and subduction of the [[Pacific Plate]] under the [[Okhotsk Plate]] to the north. Japan was originally attached to the eastern coast of the [[Eurasia]]n continent. The subducting plates, being deeper than the Eurasian plate, pulled Japan eastward, opening the [[Sea of Japan]] around 15 million years ago.{{cite web|url=http://shinku.nichibun.ac.jp/jpub/pdf/jr/IJ1501.pdf|author=Barnes, Gina L.|title=Origins of the Japanese Islands: The New "Big Picture"|publisher=[[University of Durham]]|date=2003|accessdate=August 11, 2009}} The [[Strait of Tartary]] and the [[Korea Strait]] opened much later. Today the Japanese archipelago is considered a mature island arc and is the result of several generations of subducting plates. Approximately 15,000 km of oceanic floor has passed under the Japanese area in the last 450 million years, with most being fully subducted. Japan is situated in a [[Volcano|volcanic]] zone on the [[Pacific Ring of Fire]]. Frequent low intensity earth tremors and occasional volcanic activity are felt throughout the islands. Destructive earthquakes, often resulting in [[tsunami]]s, occur several times a century.{{clear left}} ==History== Although there is mention of an earthquake in [[Yamato province|Yamato]] in what is now [[Nara Prefecture]] on August 23, 416, the first to be reliably documented took place in Nara prefecture on May 28, 599 during the reign of [[Empress Suiko]], destroying buildings throughout [[Yamato province]].Hammer, Joshua. (2006). ''Yokohama Burning: The Deadly 1923 Earthquake and Fire that Helped Forge the Path to World War II,'' p. 62–63.Ishibashi, K. (2004); "[http://www.earth-prints.org/bitstream/2122/763/1/02Ishibashi.pdf Status of historical seismology in Japan]" (30 pages); Earthquake catalogue 47 (2–3); Collections: 04.06.05. Historical seismology; Annals of Geophysics, accessed 2011-03-19 ([http://www.earth-prints.org/handle/2122/763 English summary])[[Tatsuo Usami]] "Historical earthquakes in Japan", In: William H.K. Lee, Hiroo Kanamori, Paul C. Jennings and Carl Kisslinger, (Eds.), ''International Geophysics'', Academic Press, 2002, Volume 81, Part 1, International Handbook of Earthquake and Engineering Seismology, pp. 799–802, ISSN 0074-6142, {{ISBN|978-0-12-440652-0}}, {{DOI|10.1016/S0074-6142(02)80254-6}} Many historical records of Japanese earthquakes exist, and the [[Imperial Earthquake Investigation Committee]] was created in 1892 to conduct a systematic collation of the available historical data, published in 1899 as the ''Catalogue of Historical Data on Japanese Earthquakes''. Following the [[1923 Great Kantō earthquake]], the Imperial Earthquake Investigation Committee was superseded by the [[Earthquake Research Institute, University of Tokyo|Earthquake Research Institute]] in 1925. In modern times, the catalogues compiled by [[Tatsuo Usami]] are considered to provide the most authoritative source of information on historic earthquakes, with the 2003 edition detailing 486 that took place between 416 and 1888. ==Earthquake measurement== In Japan, the [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|''shindo'' scale]] is commonly used to measure earthquakes by [[Seismic scales#Seismic intensity scales|seismic intensity]] instead of magnitude. This is similar to the [[Modified Mercalli scale]] used in the United States or the [[Liedu scale]] used in China, meaning that the scale measures the intensity of an earthquake at a given location instead of measuring the energy an earthquake releases at its epicenter (its magnitude) as the Richter scale does.{{cite web|url=http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e2116.html|title=Earthquakes|publisher=Japan Guide|accessdate=August 11, 2009}} Unlike other seismic intensity scales, which normally have twelve levels of intensity, {{nihongo|''shindo''|震度||seismic intensity, literally "degree of shaking"}} as used by the [[Japan Meteorological Agency]] is a unit with ten levels, ranging from ''shindo'' zero, a very light tremor, to ''shindo'' seven, a severe earthquake. Intermediate levels for earthquakes with ''shindo'' five and six are "weak" or "strong", according to the degree of destruction they cause. Earthquakes measured at ''shindo'' four and lower are considered to be weak to mild, while those measured at five and above can cause heavy damage to [[furniture]], wall [[tile]]s, [[wood]]en houses, [[reinforced concrete]] buildings, [[roads]], [[gas pipe|gas]] and [[water pipe]]s. ==Earthquakes== {{Expand list|date=May 2015}} {|class="wikitable sortable" id="stripe" !Date ![[Seismic scale#Magnitude scales|Magnitude]] !Death toll !class="unsortable"|Name of quake !class="unsortable"|Japanese name !class="unsortable"|Rōmaji name ![[Epicenter]] !class="unsortable"|Description |- | {{dts|684|11|29}} ([[Gregorian calendar]])

The death toll associated with this event is uncertain, but 31,000 casualties were reported.reported.http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/results?eq_0=7383&t=101650&s=18&d=99,91,95,93&nd=display |- | {{dts|1586|01|18}} || 7.9 ''MK'' || || Tensho or Ise Bay earthquake || 天正大地震 || ''Tenshō Daijishin''|| || Some islands in Ise Bay reportedly disappeared{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7F5aZna9n6kC&pg=PA125|author1=Yuji Kanaori |author2=Kazuhiro Tanaka |author3=Masahiro Chigira | title= Engineering geological advances in Japan for the new millennium| publisher=Elsevier| year=2000|isbn=9780080530925 }}{{cite web |url=https://www.gsj.jp/en/publications/reports/h10seika/10seika.html |author1=Toshihiko Sugai |author2=Yuichiro Fusejima |author3=Yasuo Awata |author4=Takashi Azuma |author5=Yoshihiko Kariya |author6=Yasuhiro Suzuki |title=Late Holocene paleoseismicity of the Yoro fault system |publisher=National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology}} |- | {{dts|1605|02|03}} || ''7.9 MK'' ||{{Hs|005000}}5,000+{{cite web|url=http://anshin.pref.tokushima.jp/normal/disaster_center/news.html?cid%3Ddisaster_center_126104359478%26nid%3D126665471905 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308220426/http://anshin.pref.tokushima.jp/normal/disaster_center/news.html?cid=disaster_center_126104359478&nid=126665471905 |archivedate=2012-03-08 |df= }}||[[1605 Nankai earthquake]] || 慶長大地震 || ''Keichō Daijishin'' ||{{coord|33.5|138.5}} || The 1605 Keichō Nankaidō earthquake occurred at about 20:00 local time on 3 February. It had an estimated magnitude of 7.9 on the [[surface wave magnitude]] scale and triggered a devastating tsunami that resulted in thousands of deaths in the Nankai and [[Tōkai region|Tōkai]] regions of [[Japan]]. It is uncertain whether there were two separate earthquakes separated by a short time interval or a single event. It is referred to as a [[tsunami earthquake]], in that the size of the tsunami greatly exceeds that expected from the magnitude of the earthquake.{{cite journal|last=Ishibashi|first=K.|year=2004|title=Status of historical seismology in Japan|journal=Annals of Geophysics|volume=47|issue=2/3|pages=339–368|url=http://www.earth-prints.org/bitstream/2122/763/1/02Ishibashi.pdf|accessdate=2009-11-22}} |- | {{dts|1611|09|27}} || ''6.9 MK'' ||{{Hs|003700}}3,700+ (Official estimate) || 1611 Aizu earthquake || 会津地震 || ''Aizu Jishin'' || Aizu basin, (Present day of [[Fukushima Prefecture]]) || According to official estimated report, more than 3,700 human fatalities. [[Aizuwakamatsu Castle]], many temples, and 20,000 houses collapsed in the damaged areas. |- | {{dts|1611|12|02}} || 8.1 ||{{Hs|002000}}2,000+ ||[[1611 Sanriku earthquake]] || 慶長三陸地震 || ''Keicho Sanriku Daijishin'' || {{coord|39.0|144.4}} || Occurred on December 2, 1611 with an epicenter off the [[Sanriku]] coast in Iwate Prefecture. The [[Moment magnitude scale|magnitude]] of the [[earthquake]] was 8.1M.{{cite web|url=http://hnn.us/articles/139314.html|title=History News Network - Danger in the Lowground: The Japan Earthquake in Historical Context|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}} |- | {{dts|1662|6|16}} || 7¼ - 7.6M || 700-900[http://www.bousai.go.jp/kyoiku/kyokun/kyoukunnokeishou/rep/1662_kanbun_omiwakasa_jishin/index.html 報告書（1662 寛文近江・若狭地震）] Cebinet Office（Japan）Retrieved 2018-03-05|| 1662 Kanbun Ōmi and Wakasa earthquake || 寛文近江・若狭地震 || ''kanbun Ōmi wakasa jishin'' || [[Lake Biwa]] south || Strong tremor in Ōmi · Wakasa area. This earthquake is causing crustal deformation(East of [[Lake Suigetsu]]：Rose 4.5 meter).Susumu Yamaga「日本列島の地震・津波・噴火の歴史」p72-73.2018-03-05 Reading. {{ISBN|978-4-86064-476-5}} |- | {{dts|1703|12|31}} || 8.0 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|005233}} 5,233 ||[[1703 Genroku earthquake]] || 元禄大地震 || ''Genroku Daijishin'' || [[Edo]] || This earthquake shook Edo and killed an estimated 2,300 people. The earthquake is thought to have been an interplate earthquake whose focal region extended from [[Sagami Bay]] to the tip of the [[Bōsō Peninsula]] as well as the area along the [[Sagami Trough]] in the open sea southeast of the Boso Peninsula. This earthquake then resulted in a [[tsunami]] which hit the coastal areas of the Boso Peninsula and Sagami Bay. The tsunami was reported to have caused more than 10,000 fatalities. |- | {{dts|1707|10|28}} || 8.6 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|005000}}5,000+ ||[[1707 Hōei earthquake]] || 宝永地震 || ''Hōei jishin'' || Off the [[Kii Peninsula]] || Struck both the [[Nankaidō]] and [[Tōkai region]]s, causing moderate to severe damage throughout southwestern [[Honshu]], [[Shikoku]] and southeastern [[Kyūshū]].{{cite web|format=[[PDF]] |url=http://www.dpri.kyoto-u.ac.jp/dat/nenpo/no48/48c0/a48c0p13.pdf |title=Historical maximum seismic intensity maps in Japan from 1586 to 2004: construction of database and application |last=Miyazawa |first=M. |author2=Mori J. |year=2005 |work=Ann. Disaster Prev. Res. Inst. Kyoto Univ. |volume=48C |accessdate=30 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722072314/https://www.dpri.kyoto-u.ac.jp/dat/nenpo/no48/48c0/a48c0p13.pdf |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df= }} |- | {{dts|1771|04|24}} || 7.4 ''MK'' ||{{Hs|013486}}13,486{{cite web|url=http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/results?eq_0=1405&t=101650&s=13&d=22,26,13,12&nd=display|title=Significant Earthquake|author=Paula Dunbar|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}}||[[1771 Great Yaeyama Tsunami]] || 八重山地震 || ''Yaeyama jishin'' || {{coord|24.0|124.3}} || The 1771 Great Yaeyama Tsunami (also called 明和の大津波, the Great Tsunami of Meiwa) was caused by the Yaeyama Great Earthquake at about 8 A.M. on April 24. 13,486 people (including 9,313 in [[Yaeyama Islands]] (8,815 in [[Ishigaki Island]]), 2,548 in [[Miyako Islands]] and 1,625 in other areas) were confirmed to be dead or missing and more than 3,000 houses were destroyed. The height of the [[tsunami]] was over 40 meters at [[Ishigaki Island]], up to a maximum of 85.4 meters in the village called Miyara. In [[Tarama]], estimated tsunami runup height was approximately 18 meters. To this day, boulders reportedly launched by the tsunami (called "tsunami stones") remain in the northwestern highlands of [[Miyakojima]]. According to unverified local legend, a small unnamed [[island]] in the area was swallowed by the tsunami and disappeared. |- | {{dts|1792|05|21}} || 6.4 ''MK'' ||{{Hs|015448}}15,448{{cite web|url=http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/results?eq_0=1515&t=101650&s=13&d=22,26,13,12&nd=display|title=Significant Earthquake|author=Paula Dunbar|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}}||[[1792 Unzen earthquake and tsunami]] || 島原大変肥後迷惑 || ''Unzen jishin''
(''Shimabara Taihen Higo Meiwaku'') || {{coord|32.8|130.3}} ||[[File:Ariake sea coastline.png|thumb|Changes to the Ariake Sea coastline, in the center of Mount Unzen, Kumamoto Prefecture (right) and the Amakusa Islands (see below) were affected by the tsunami]] An earthquake caused by volcanic activity of [[Mount Unzen]] (in the Shimabara Peninsula [[Nagasaki]], Japan). It killed 15,000 people altogether, due in large part to a tsunami that was triggered by the collapse of nearby Mount Mayuyama's southern flank into the bay. The incident is also referred to with the phrase '[[Shimabara, Nagasaki|Shimabara]] erupted, Higo affected' (岛原大変肥后迷惑), as many people in Higo, ([[Kumamoto]], located 20 km away across the [[Ariake Sea]]) were also killed by the resulting tsunami, which then bounced back to hit Shimabara again. |- | {{dts|1828|12|18}} || 6.9 ''MK ||{{Hs|001559}}1,559 (official confirmed) || 1828 Echigo Sanjō earthquake || 越後三条地震 || ''Echigo Sanjō Jishin'' || [[Sanjo, Niigata|Sanjo, Niigata Prefecture]] (then [[Echigo Province]]) || According to the official confirmed report, 21,134 houses and buildings were damaged, and 1,204 of them burned down. There were 1,559 human fatalities, and 2,666 injured people in the affected area. |- | {{dts|1847|05|08}} || 7.3 M ||{{Hs|008600}}8,600+ ||[[1847 Nagano earthquake]] || 善光寺地震 || ''Zenkōji Jishin'' || Nagano Basin (then [[Shinano Province]])|| In the central area of Nagano, many buildings collapsed, including Zenkōji temple. The earthquake triggered a complex variety of resulting disasters, which included fires, landslides, and flooding due to the formation and subsequent collapse of a "dam" made of debris from the collapsed buildings. According to the confirmed official report, the death toll throughout the region reached at least 8,600. 21,000 houses were damaged and 3,400 burned, and an additional 44,000 homes were damaged by the landslides in the area. |- | {{dts|1854|07|09}} || 7.25 'MK ||{{Hs|000995}}995 (official confirmed) || 1854 Iga Ueno earthquake || 伊賀上野地震 || ''Iga Ueno Jishin'' || [[Iga, Mie|Iga, Mie Prefecture]] (then [[Iga Province]]) || According to the official confirmed report, 2,576 houses and buildings were damaged, with 995 human fatalities and 994 injures in the affected area. |- | {{dts|1854|12|23}} || 8.4 ''MK'' ||{{Hs|002000}}2,000 (estimated){{cite journal|last=Usami|first=T.|year=1979|title=Study of Historical Earthquakes in Japan|journal=Bulletin of the Earthquake Research Institute|volume=54|pages=399–439|url=http://repository.dl.itc.u-tokyo.ac.jp/dspace/bitstream/2261/12734/1/ji0543001.pdf|accessdate=2009-11-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722080425/http://repository.dl.itc.u-tokyo.ac.jp/dspace/bitstream/2261/12734/1/ji0543001.pdf|archive-date=2011-07-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}||[[1854 Tōkai earthquake]] || 安政東海地震 || ''Ansei Tōkai Jishin'' || [[Suruga Bay]] || The [[epicenter]] ranged from Suruga Bay to the deep ocean, and the quake struck primarily in the [[Tōkai region]], but destroyed houses as far away as in [[Edo]]. The accompanying [[tsunami]] caused damage along the entire coast from the [[Bōsō Peninsula]] in modern-day [[Chiba prefecture]] to [[Tosa province]] (modern-day [[Kōchi Prefecture]]).Kawade Shobō Shinsha Editorial Team (eds.). "Ansei Daijishin" (安政大地震, "Great Earthquakes of Ansei"). ''Ō-Edo Rekishi Hyakka'' (大江戸歴史百科, "Historical Encyclopedia of Great Edo"). Tokyo: Kawade Shobō Shinsha Publishers, 2007, p. 253. |- | {{dts|1854|12|24}} || 8.4 ''MK'' ||{{Hs|010000}}10,000+ ||[[1854 Nankai earthquake]] || 安政南海地震 || ''Ansei Nankai Jishin'' || [[Nankai Trough]] || Over 10,000 people from the Tōkai region down to Kyushu were killed. |- | {{dts|1855|11|11}} || 6.9 ''MK'' ||{{Hs|006641 !}}6,641 ||[[1855 Edo earthquake]] || 安政江戸地震 || ''Ansei Edo Jishin'' || [[Edo]], near the mouth of the [[Arakawa River (Kanto)|Arakawa River]] || One hundred and twenty earthquakes and tremors in total were felt in Edo in 1854–55. The great earthquake struck after 10 o'clock in the evening; roughly 30 aftershocks ensued, continuing until dawn. Records from the time indicate 6,641 deaths inside the city and 2,759 injuries; much of the city was destroyed by fire, leading many people to stay in rural inns. Aftershocks continued for twenty days. |- | {{dts|1858|04|09}} || 7.0 ||{{Hs|000200}}200–300 ||[[1858 Hietsu earthquake]] || 飛越地震|飛越地震 || ''Hietsu Jishin'' || Atotsugawa Fault || It occurred on the Atotsugawa Fault, which connects [[Mount Tate]] in [[Toyama Prefecture]] and the Amō Pass in [[Gifu Prefecture]] on the island of [[Honshū]] in [[Japan]]. Its name includes one [[kanji]] from {{Nihongo|[[Hida Province|Hida]]|飛騨国}} and one from {{Nihongo|[[Etchū Province|Etchū]]|越中国}}, the names of the provinces that were in use at the time. The earthquake is estimated to have killed 200–300 people. It also caused the [[Mount Tonbi]] Landslide and blocked the upper reaches of the [[Jōganji River]].{{cite web|url=http://cais.gsi.go.jp/KAIHOU/kaihou33/03_05.pdf|title=The Hietsu Earthquake of April 9, 1858 and the Omachi Earthquake of April 23, 1858|last=Usami|first=Tatsuo|format=PDF|language=Japanese|publisher=Earthquake Research Institute, University of Tokyo|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304141331/http://cais.gsi.go.jp/KAIHOU/kaihou33/03_05.pdf|archivedate=March 4, 2009|df=}} |- | {{dts|1872|03|18}} || 7.1 ''MK ||{{Hs|000551}}551 (official confirmed) || 1872 Hamada earthquake || 浜田地震 || ''Hamada Jishin'' || off coast [[Hamada, Shimane|Hamada, Shimane Prefecture]] || According to the official confirmed report, 4506 houses were damaged by the earthquake, 230 houses were burned, 551 people were killed, and landslides destroyed 6567 homes in the affected area. This quake occurred at 16:40 local time. |- | {{dts|1880|02|22}} || 5.5-6.0 || 0 || 1880 Yokohama earthquake || 横浜地震 || ''Yokohama Jishin'' || Yokohama City || The damage was minor. However, The Japan Seismological Society was established on the occasion of this.[https://typhoon.yahoo.co.jp/weather/calendar/173/ 横浜地震（1880年）] Japan,Yahoo（Japanese）Retrieval 2018/04/06 |- | {{dts|1889|07|28}} || 6.3 ||{{Hs|000020}}20 ||[[1889 Kumamoto earthquake]] || 熊本地震|熊本地震 ||''Kumamoto Jishin'' || Tatsuda fault || First major earthquake after the establishment of the [[Seismological Society of Japan]] in 1880. |- | {{dts|1891|10|28}} || 8.0 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|007273}}7,273 ||[[1891 Mino–Owari earthquake]] || 美濃・尾張地震 || ''Mino Owari Jishin'' || [[Neodani Fault]] || A large earthquake that struck the former [[Provinces of Japan|provinces]] of [[Mino Province|Mino]] and [[Owari Province|Owari]] in the [[Nōbi Plain]] area during the [[Meiji period]] in [[Japan]]. It is also referred to as the '''Nōbi Earthquake''' (濃尾地震 ''Nōbi Jishin'') or the '''Great Nōbi Earthquake''' (濃尾大地震 ''Nōbi Daijishin''). |- | {{dts|1894|06|20}} || 6.6 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|000031}}31 ||[[1894 Tokyo earthquake]] || 明治東京地震 || ''Meiji-Tokyo Jishin'' || [[Tokyo Bay]] || This earthquake occurred in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] at 14:04 on June 20, 1894. It affected downtown Tokyo and neighboring [[Kanagawa prefecture]], especially the cities of [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa|Kawasaki]] and [[Yokohama]].{{cite web|url=http://sciencelinks.jp/j-east/article/199920/000019992099A0772172.php|title=Source Parameters of the Tokyo Earthquake in Meiji Era (1894).|publisher=Japan Science and Technology Agency|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090730040328/http://sciencelinks.jp/j-east/article/199920/000019992099A0772172.php|archivedate=2009-07-30|df=}} The depth of the 1894 earthquake has not been determined, but it is thought to have occurred within the subducting [[Pacific Plate]] under the [[Kantō region]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hp1039.jishin.go.jp/eqchreng/5-1-3.htm|title=Inland earthquakes|publisher=The Headquarters for Earthquake Research Promotion}} The death toll was 31 killed and 157 injured. |- | {{dts|1894|10|22}} || 7.0 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|000726}}726 (Official confirmed) || 1894 Shōkai earthquake || 庄内地震 || ''Shōnai Jishin'' || [[Sakata, Yamagata|Sakata]], [[Yamagata Prefecture]] || According to the official confirmed report, 14,118 houses and buildings were damaged and 2,148 were burned. There were 726 human fatalities and 8,403 people injured in the damaged area. A large-scale fire broke out in Sakata, and around the Shonai plain area, many instances of cracked earth, sinking ground, sand boils, and fountains were observed. |- | {{dts|1896|06|15}} || 8.5 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|022000}}22,000+{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/today/index.php?month=6&day=15&submit=View+Date|title=Today in Earthquake History|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}}||[[1896 Sanriku earthquake]] || 明治三陸地震 || ''Meiji Sanriku Jishin'' ||   || This quake occurred off the coast of [[Sanriku, Iwate|Sanriku]] in [[Iwate Prefecture]], which caused a [[tsunami]] of {{convert|25|m|ft|abbr=on}} to strike 35 minutes after the quake, destroying hundreds of houses and killed over 22,000 people. Tsunami were also observed as far away as Hawaii and in California.{{cite web|url=http://www.agu.org/news/press/pr_archives/1996-1999/sanriku.html|title=Research describes origin of devastating tsunami|publisher=American Geophysical Union|date=1996-06-12|accessdate=2009-05-19}}{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/regional/world/events/1896_06_15.php|title=Historic Earthquakes: Sanriku, Japan, 1896 June 15 UTC , Magnitude 8.5|publisher=[[US Geological Survey]]|date=2009-01-29|accessdate=2009-05-19}} |- | {{dts|1923|09|01}} || 8.3 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|142800}} 142,800{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/today/index.php?month=9&day=1&submit=View+Date|title=Today in Earthquake History|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}}||[[1923 Great Kantō earthquake]] || 大正関東地震
(関東大震災) || ''Taishō Kantō Jishin''
(''Kantō Daishinsai'') || [[Izu Ōshima]] || An earthquake which struck the [[Kantō]] plain on the [[Japan]]ese main island of [[Honshū]] at 11:58 on the morning of September 1, 1923. Varied accounts hold that the duration of the earthquake was between 4 and 10 minutes. The quake had an epicenter deep beneath [[Izu Ōshima]] Island in [[Sagami Bay]]. It devastated [[Tokyo]], the port city of [[Yokohama]], and the surrounding prefectures of [[Chiba Prefecture|Chiba]], [[Kanagawa Prefecture|Kanagawa]], and [[Shizuoka Prefecture|Shizuoka]], and caused widespread damage throughout the Kantō region.Hammer, Joshua. (2006). [https://books.google.com/books?id=6O8VyhDbUPgC ''Yokohama Burning: the Deadly 1923 Earthquake and Fire that Helped Forge the Path to World War II,'' p. 278], citing Francis Hawks, (1856). ''Narrative of the Expedition of an American Squadron to the China Seas and Japan Performed in the Years 1852, 1853 and 1854 under the Command of Commodore M.C. Perry, United States Navy,'' Washington: A.O.P. Nicholson by order of Congress, 1856; originally published in ''Senate Executive Documents'', No. 34 of 33rd Congress, 2nd Session. The power and intensity of the earthquake is easy to underestimate, but the 1923 earthquake managed to move the 93-ton [[Kōtoku-in|Great Buddha]] statue at [[Kamakura, Kanagawa|Kamakura]]. The statue slid forward almost two feet.Great Buddha: [http://pacific-islander.blogspot.com/2007/10/all-buddhas-great-and-small.html blog] Casualty estimates range up to about 142,800 deaths, a figure including approximately 40,000 who went missing and were presumed dead. |- | {{dts|1925|05|23}} || 6.8 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|000428}}428 ||1925 Kita Tajima earthquake || 北但馬地震 || ''Kita Tajima Jishin'' || [[Toyooka]] in [[Hyōgo Prefecture]] ||This earthquake's epicenter was (35.6 degrees north latitude, 134.8 degrees east longitude), in the Maruyama River estuary. According to the Japanese government's official report, there were 428 human fatalities, 1,016 people injured, 7,863 buildings destroyed, and 45,659 houses damaged by collapse or fire. This quake caused extensive damage to the town of Toyooka and the Maruyama River area. Just before the shaking could be felt, a sound like a cannon was reportedly heard intermittently from the direction of the estuary near the Maruyama River. During the earthquake, the ground in the town of Tokyooka experienced strong seismic vibrations for 16 seconds. As most of the buildings of the time were wooden, many of them were destroyed at once during the initial earthquake. In the fire that broke out subsequently, half of Toyooka was burned down, with many deaths resulting (a reported 8% of the town's population.) 272 deaths were confirmed to have occurred in the Kinosaki area. |- | {{dts|1927|03|07}} || 7.6 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|003020}}3,020 ||[[1927 Kita Tango earthquake]] || 北丹後地震 || ''Kita Tango Jishin'' || [[Tango Peninsula]] in [[Kyoto Prefecture]] || Almost all of the houses in Mineyama (now part of [[Kyōtango, Kyoto|Kyōtango]]) were destroyed, and the quake was felt as far away as [[Tokyo]] and [[Kagoshima]].{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/regional/world/events/1927_03_07.php|title=Historic Earthquakes: Tango, Japan, 1927 March 07 09:27 UTC, Magnitude 7.6|publisher=[[USGS]]|accessdate=2009-05-19}} |- | {{dts|1930|11|26}} || 7.3 ''Ms'' ||{{Hs|000272}}272 ||[[1930 North Izu earthquake]] || 1930年北伊豆地震 || ''Sen-kyūhyaku-sanjū-nen Kita-Izu Jishin'' || [[Izu Peninsula]] || |- | {{dts|1933|03|02}} || 8.4 ''Mw''{{cite web|url=http://www.gps.caltech.edu/uploads/File/People/kanamori/HKjgr77.pdf |title=Kanamori, H., 1977, The energy release of great earthquakes, ''J. Geophys. Res.'' 82, 2981-2987. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723182215/http://www.gps.caltech.edu/uploads/File/People/kanamori/HKjgr77.pdf |archivedate=2010-07-23 |df= }} ||{{Hs|003000}}3,000+ ||[[1933 Sanriku earthquake]] || 昭和三陸地震 || ''Shōwa Sanriku Jishin'' || {{convert|290|km|mi|abbr=on}} east of the city of [[Kamaishi, Iwate]] ||[[File:Kamaishi Bay after 1933 tsunami.jpg|right|250px|thumb|Kamaishi Bay, Iwate after 1933 earthquake and tsunami]] A major [[earthquake]] whose associated [[tsunami]] caused widespread damage to towns on the [[Iwate Prefecture|Sanriku]] coast of the [[Tōhoku region]] of [[Honshū]], [[Japan]] in 1933.{{cite web |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/regional/world/events/1933_03_02.php |title=Historical Earthquakes:The 1933 Sanriku earthquake |accessdate=2008-07-16 |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] |date=14 March 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724115436/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/regional/world/events/1933_03_02.php |archive-date=2008-07-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }} |- | {{dts|1936|11|03}} || 7.2 ''Ms'' ||0||[[1936 Miyagi earthquake]] || 1936年宮城県沖地震 || ''Sen-kyūhyaku-sanjūroku-nen Miyagi-ken-oki Jishin'' || offshore [[Miyagi Prefecture|Miyagi]] | |- | {{dts|1943|09|10}} || 7.2 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|001083}}1,083 ||[[1943 Tottori earthquake]] || 鳥取地震 || ''Tottori Jishin'' || offshore from [[Ketaka District, Tottori|Ketaka District]] || An earthquake which occurred in [[Tottori prefecture]], [[Japan]] at 17:36 on September 10, 1943. Although the earthquake occurred during [[World War II]], information about the disaster was surprisingly [[Censorship in the Empire of Japan|uncensored]], and relief volunteers and supplies came from many parts of the Japanese empire, including [[Manchukuo]]. The Tottori earthquake had its [[epicenter]] offshore from [[Ketaka District, Tottori|Ketaka District]], now part of [[Tottori, Tottori|Tottori city]], with a magnitude of 7.2 on the [[Richter magnitude scale|Richter Scale]]. The magnitude of the earthquake was 6.0 in Tottori city, and 5.0 as far away as [[Okayama, Okayama|Okayama]] on the [[Seto Inland Sea|Inland Sea]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hp1039.jishin.go.jp/eqchreng/8-2-2.htm|title=The Tottori Earthquake (September 10, 1943, M 7.2)|publisher=The Headquarters for Earthquake Research Promotion}} |- | {{dts|1944|12|07}} || 8.1 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|001223}}1,223 ||[[1944 Tōnankai earthquake]] || 昭和東南海地震 || ''Shōwa Tōnankai Jishin'' || {{coord|34.0|137.1}} || This earthquake occurred on Dec. 7, 1944, at 13:35 local time (04:35 UTC). Its [[moment magnitude scale|moment magnitude]] was 8.1 and it was felt with a maximum intensity of 5 on the [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|Shindo scale]] (or VII, "Severe", on the [[Mercalli intensity scale]]). It struck the provinces along the coast of the [[Tōkai region]], causing serious damage and triggering a tsunami. The [[earthquake]] and [[tsunami]] combined killed 1,223 people, with injuries reported to have affected 20,000 people or more.{{cite web|url=http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/results?eq_0=3791&t=101650&s=13&d=22,26,13,12&nd=display|title=Significant Earthquake|author=Paula Dunbar|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}} |- | {{dts|1945|01|13}} || 6.8 ''ML'' ||{{Hs|001180}}1180 + 1126 missing ||[[1945 Mikawa earthquake]] || 三河地震 || ''Mikawa Jishin'' || [[Mikawa Bay]] || An earthquake which occurred off [[Mie prefecture|Mie]] and [[Aichi prefecture]]s, [[Japan]] at 03:38 on January 13, 1945. As the earthquake occurred during [[World War II]], information about the disaster was [[Censorship in the Empire of Japan|censored]], and efforts at keeping the disaster secret hampered relief efforts and contributed to a high death toll.{{Cite journal|url=http://bases.bireme.br/cgi-bin/wxislind.exe/iah/online/?IsisScript=iah/iah.xis&src=google&base=DESASTRES&lang=p&nextAction=lnk&exprSearch=1920&indexSearch=ID|title=Interpretation of damage to houses and casualties relied on a precise evaluation of earthquake ground motions in the epicentral region: 1945 Mikawa earthquake|journal=En|pages=378–393|last1=Inada|first1=Osamu|last2=Mochizuki|first2=Toshio|last3=Miura|first3=Fusanori|last4=Taniguchi|first4=Hitoshi}} The Mikawa earthquake had its [[epicenter]] offshore in [[Mikawa Bay]] ({{coord|34|42.1|N|137|6.8|E|type:event}} at a depth of eleven kilometers). The city of [[Tsu, Mie|Tsu]] recorded a magnitude of 6 on the [[Richter magnitude scale|Richter Scale]]; however, areas in southern Aichi prefecture were closer to the epicenter, and suffered significant damage. |- | {{dts|1946|12|20}} || 8.1 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|001362}}1,362 ||[[1946 Nankai earthquake]] || 昭和南海地震 || ''Shōwa Nankai Jishin'' || [[Nankai Trough]] || A major [[earthquake]] in [[Nankaidō]], [[Japan]]. Occurred on December 20, 1946 at 19:19 UTC. The earthquake was felt from Northern [[Honshū]] to [[Kyūshū]].{{cite web |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/regional/world/events/1946_12_20.php |title=The 1946 Nankaido earthquake |accessdate=2008-06-29 |publisher=[[USGS]] |date=13 March 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080601172947/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/regional/world/events/1946_12_20.php |archive-date=2008-06-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }} |- | {{dts|1948|06|28}} || 7.1 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|003769}}3,769 ||[[1948 Fukui earthquake]] || 福井地震 || ''Fukui Jishin'' || near [[Maruoka, Fukui]] || A major [[earthquake]] in [[Fukui Prefecture]], [[Japan]]. It struck at 5:13 p.m. on June 28, 1948 (the then Japan Daylight Saving Time; JDT). The strongest shaking occurred in the city of [[Fukui, Fukui|Fukui]], where it was recorded as 6 (equivalent to the current 7) on the [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale]]. The coordinates of the earthquake were 36゜10.3'N　136゜17.4'E (around the town of [[Maruoka, Fukui|Maruoka]]).[http://www.seisvol.kishou.go.jp/cgi-bin/shindo_db.cgi?from_YYYY=1948&from_MM=01&from_DD=01&from_hh=00&from_mm=00&to_YYYY=1949&to_MM=01&to_DD=01&to_hh=24&to_mm=00&ORG_PID=24403&pref=40&minimum_shindo=7&station=9999999&max_count=5&PARAM_OK_DATE=%B8%A1%BA%F7%BC%C2%B9%D4 Japan Meteorological Agency]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Shindo Database Search Retrieved August 16, 2008 |- | {{dts|1952|03|04}} || 8.1 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000028}}28 ||[[1952 Hokkaido earthquake]] || 1952年十勝沖地震 || ''Sen-kyūhyaku-goūjūni-nen Tokachi-Oki Jishin'' || {{coord|42.3|144.9}} || The 1952 Hokkaido [[earthquake]] took place around March 4, 1952 in the sea east of [[Hokkaido]]. On the [[Moment magnitude scale]], it measured 8.1. Casualties occurred due to the earthquake.{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/learn/today/index.php?month=3&day=4&submit=View+Date|title=Today in Earthquake History|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}} |- | {{dts|1961|08|19}} || 7.0 || 8 || 1961 Mino earthquake || 北美濃地震 || ''Kitamino Jishin'' || {{coord|36|6|7|N|136|42|0|E}} || One of the earthquakes that the Japan Meteorological Agency named for the.[https://www.jma.go.jp/jma/kishou/know/meimei/meimei2.html 気象庁が命名した気象及び地震火山現象] Japan Meteorological Agency（Japanese）Retrieval 2018/04/06 8 people dead.[http://www.pref.gifu.lg.jp/kurashi/bosai/shizen-saigai/11115/jishin-saigai.html 岐阜県の地震災害] Gifu Prefecture Official Site（Japanese）Retrieval 2018/04/06 |- | {{dts|1964|06|16}} || 7.6 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000026}}26 ||[[1964 Niigata earthquake]] || 新潟地震 || ''Niigata Jishin'' || 50 km north of [[Niigata, Niigata|Niigata]] || The earthquake caused widespread [[soil liquefaction]] in the city of Niigata, resulting in unusually high levels of damage to buildings for the felt intensity.{{cite book|last=Kawasumi|first=H.|editor=Kawasumi H.|title=General Report on the Niigata Earthquake of 1964|chapter-url=http://www.iris.edu/seismo/quakes/1964niigata/Kawasumi1968.pdf|year=1968|publisher=Tokyo Electrical Engineering College Press|location=Tokyo, Japan|chapter=1. Introduction}} |- | {{dts|1968|04|01}} || 7.5 ''Mw'' ||0||[[1968 Hyūga-nada earthquake]] || 1968年日向灘地震 || ''Sen-kyūhyaku-rokujūhachi-nen Hyūga-nada Jishin'' || Hyūga-nada Sea |{{cite web|url=http://walrus.wr.usgs.gov/reports/reprints/Geist_JGR_107.pdf|title=jb000139 1..16|publisher=}} |- | {{dts|1968|05|16}} || 8.2 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000052}}52 ||[[1968 Tokachi earthquake]] || 1968年十勝沖地震 || ''Sen-kyūhyaku-rokujūhachi-nen Tokachi-oki Jishin'' || Offshore of [[Misawa, Japan]] || This earthquake struck off the coast of [[Honshu Island]], near Misawa Japan, [[Aomori Prefecture]], and was followed by a significant tsunami. The earthquake and ensuing tsunami claimed 52 lives and resulted in significant material damage in Northern Japan.{{cite web|url=http://geology.com/noaa/pacific-ocean-tsunami/|title=Maps of Pacific Ocean Tsunami Travel Times|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]|accessdate=20 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.misawajapan.com/aboutmisawa/then-now.asp|title=History of Misawa Air Base|publisher=MisawaJapan.com |accessdate=20 March 2011}} |- | {{dts|1974|05|09}} || 6.5 ''Ms'' ||{{Hs|000025}}25 ||[[1974 Izu Peninsula earthquake]] || 1974年伊豆半島沖地震 || ''Sen-kyūhyaku-nanajūyo-nen Izu-hantō-oki Jishin'' || near [[Izu Peninsula]] || |- | {{dts|1978|06|12}} || 7.7 ''Ms'' ||{{Hs|000028}}28 ||[[1978 Miyagi earthquake]] || 宮城県沖地震 || ''Miyagi-ken-oki jishin'' || just offshore [[Miyagi Prefecture]] || Damage was greatest around [[Sendai]], and the earthquake triggered widespread landslides.{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqarchives/significant/sig_1978.php|title=Significant Earthquakes of the World 1978|last=USGS|accessdate=6 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100123173040/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eqarchives/significant/sig_1978.php|archivedate=23 January 2010|df=}}{{cite book|last1=Sidle|first1=R.C.|last2=Pearce|first2=A.J.|last3=O'Loughlin|first3=C.L.|title=Hillslope stability and land use |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eRq20MrJhBUC|volume=11|year=1985|publisher=American Geophysical Union|isbn=978-0-87590-315-6|pages=1–9|chapter=1 Significance of Soil Mass Movement}} |- | {{dts|1983|05|26}} || 7.8 ''Ms'' ||{{Hs|000104}}104 ||[[1983 Sea of Japan earthquake]] || 日本海中部地震 || ''Nihonkai-chubu jishin'' || off coast 50 miles (80 kilometers)from [[Noshiro, Akita|Noshiro, Akita Prefecture]] ||Rising up to 30 feet (10 meters) above the coastline, the tsunami created by this earthquake was observed throughout a wide area along the Sea of Japan's coast and caused damage from [[Tsuruoka]] to [[Goshogawara]]. 100 people lost their lives to the tsunami, including seawall construction workers and beachgoers. In total, 104 people were killed. Soil liquification was widely observed through the affected area. |- | {{dts|1984|09|14}} || 6.3 ''Ms'' ||{{Hs|000029}}29 ||[[1984 Otaki earthquake]] || 長野県西部地震 || ''Nagano-ken-seibu jishin'' || [[Mount Ontake]], [[Otaki, Nagano|Otaki, Nagano Prefecture]] || Overall, 29 people were killed and 10 injured. |- | {{dts|1993|07|12}} || 7.7 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000202}} 202 ||[[1993 Hokkaidō earthquake]] || 北海道南西沖地震 || ''Hokkaidō Nansei Oki Jishin'' || {{coord|42.851|N|139.197|E}} || |- | {{dts|1994|12|28}} || 7.7 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000003}}3 ||[[1994 offshore Sanriku earthquake]] || 三陸はるか沖地震 || ''Sanriku-haruka-oki Jishin'' || {{coord|40.451|N|143.491|E}} ||{{cite web|url=http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nndc/struts/results?eq_0=5397&t=101650&s=13&d=22,26,13,12&nd=display|title=Significant Earthquake|author=Paula Dunbar|publisher=|accessdate=15 April 2016}} |- | {{dts|1995|01|17}} || 7.3 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|006434}}6,434 ||[[Great Hanshin earthquake]] || 兵庫県南部地震
(阪神・淡路大震災) || ''Hyōgoken Nanbu Jishin''
(''Hanshin-Awaji Daishinsai '') || northern end of [[Awaji Island]] ||[[File:Nagata001.JPG|thumbnail|180px|Damage in Kobe]] An [[earthquake]] in Japan that occurred on Tuesday January 17, 1995 at 05:46 [[Japan Standard Time|JST]] in the southern part of [[Hyōgo Prefecture]]. It measured {{M|w|link=y}} 6.8 on the [[Moment magnitude scale]] ([[United States Geological Survey|USGS]]),{{cite web|author=U.S. Geological Survey |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/eqcenter/eqarchives/significant/sig_1995.php |title=Significant Earthquakes of the World: 1995 |accessdate=2008-05-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080601182725/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/eqcenter/eqarchives/significant/sig_1995.php |archivedate=2008-06-01 |df= }} and Mj7.3 on the revised (7.2 on the old) [[Japan Meteorological Agency|JMA]] magnitude scale.{{cite web|author=The City of Kobe|date=2008-01-01|url=http://www.city.kobe.jp/cityoffice/06/013/report/january.2008.pdf|title=STATISTICS|work=The Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake: Statistics and Restoration Progress|accessdate=2008-05-25|format=PDF}} The tremors lasted for approximately 20 seconds. The hypocenter of the earthquake was located {{convert|16|km|abbr=on}} beneath its [[epicenter]], on the northern end of [[Awaji Island]], {{convert|20|km|abbr=on}} away from the city of [[Kobe]]. |- | {{dts|1998|05|04}} || 7.5 ''Mw'' || 0 ||[[1998 Ryukyu Islands earthquake]] || 石垣島南方沖地震|| ''Ishigakijima nanpō-oki jishin'' || {{coord|22.30|N|125.30|E|type:event}} || The epicentre was in the [[Philippine Sea]], far off the coast (260 km from [[Ishigaki Island]], [[Japan]], 400 km from [[Basco, Batanes|Basco]], [[Philippines]], and 425 km from [[Hualian City|Hualian]], [[Taiwan]]).{{cite web |url=http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/eq_depot/1998/eq_980503/ |title=USGS Earthquake Hazards Program: Earthquake Report: Southeast of Taiwan |publisher=Neic.usgs.gov |accessdate=2010-07-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202222802/http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/eq_depot/1998/eq_980503/ |archivedate=2010-02-02 |df= }} |- | {{dts|2001|03|24}} || 6.7 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000002}}2 ||[[2001 Geiyo earthquake]] || 2001年芸予地震 || ''Nisen-ichi-nen Gēyo Jishin'' || {{coord|34.083|N|128.020|E}} || |- | {{dts|2003|09|25}} || 8.3 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000001}}1 ||[[2003 Hokkaidō earthquake]] || 2003年十勝沖地震 || ''Nisen-san-nen Tokachi-oki Jishin'' || {{coord|41.78|N|143.86|E}} || An earthquake occurring in [[Hokkaido]] on September 25, 2003. It measured 8.3 on the [[Moment magnitude scale]] and caused extensive damage to roads all around Hokkaido, several power outages, and landslides which resulted in further damage.[http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/eq_depot/2003/eq_030925/ USGS Earthquake Hazards Program: Earthquake Report: HOKKAIDO, JAPAN REGION] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828223626/http://neic.usgs.gov/neis/eq_depot/2003/eq_030925/ |date=2008-08-28 }} |- | {{dts|2004|10|23}} || 6.9 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000040}}40 ||[[2004 Chūetsu earthquake]] || 新潟県中越地震 || ''Chūetsu Jishin'' || [[Ojiya, Niigata]] || Occurred at 5:56 p.m. (local time) on Saturday, October 23, 2004. The initial earthquake caused noticeable shaking across almost half of Honshū, including parts of the [[Tohoku region|Tohoku]], [[Hokuriku region|Hokuriku]], [[Chūbu region|Chūbu]], and [[Kantō region]]s. |- | {{dts|2005|03|20}} || 7.0 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000001}}1 ||[[2005 Fukuoka earthquake]] || 福岡県西方沖地震 || ''Fukuoka-ken Seihō Oki Jishin'' || Fukuoka PrefectureIn the [[Genkai Sea]] about {{convert|6|km|mi|abbr=on}} northwest of [[Genkai Island]] at the mouth of Fukuoka Harbor || This earthquake struck [[Fukuoka Prefecture]], [[Japan]] at 10:53:40 [[Japan Standard Time|JST]] on March 20 and lasted for approximately 50 seconds. The quake occurred along a previously unknown [[Fault (geology)|fault]] in the Genkai Sea, North of [[Fukuoka, Fukuoka|Fukuoka]] city, and the residents of [[Genkai Island]] were forced to evacuate as houses collapsed and landslides occurred in places. Investigations subsequent to the earthquake determined that the new fault was most likely an extension of the known Kego Fault that runs through the center of the city. |- | {{dts|2005|08|16}} || 7.2 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000000}}0 ||[[2005 Miyagi earthquake]] || 宮城県沖地震 || ''Miyagi-ken Oki Jishin'' || Miyagi Prefectureabout {{convert|55|km|mi|abbr=on}} due east of the [[Oshika Peninsula]] in [[Miyagi Prefecture]] || A powerful [[earthquake]] that struck the east coast of the [[Japan]]ese island of [[Honshū]] at 11:46 (02:46 [[UTC]]) on August 16, causing casualties, building collapses and [[power outage]]s. The earthquake began on Tuesday, August 16, 2005, and affected Japan's northeastern coast. It triggered a tsunami warning, and buildings shook 200 miles away in the capital, Tokyo. It was initially estimated to have a rating of 6.8., and the U.S. Geological Survey later registered it as a 7.2.{{cite web|date=August 16, 2005 |title=Quake Shakes Buildings in Tokyo |work=The Associated Press |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/02/07/light-quake-shakes-buildings-in-tokyo-no-injuries-or-damage.html |accessdate=2006-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160207185046/http://www.foxnews.com/world/2016/02/07/light-quake-shakes-buildings-in-tokyo-no-injuries-or-damage.html |archivedate=February 7, 2016 }} |- | {{dts|2006|11|15}} || 8.3 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000000}}0 ||[[2006 Kuril Islands earthquake]] || 2006年千島列島沖地震 || ''Nisen-roku-nen Chishima Rettō Oki Jishin'' || Kuril Islands about {{convert|160|km|mi|abbr=on}} due east of the southern tip of [[Simushir]] in the [[Kuril Islands]] || The earthquake happened at 20:29 [[Japan Standard Time|JST]] on November 15, 2006, causing a [[tsunami]] to hit the Japanese northern coast. |- | {{dts|2007|01|13}} || 8.1 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000000}}0 ||[[2007 Kuril Islands earthquake]] || 2007年千島列島沖地震 || ''Nisen-nana-nen Chishima Rettō Oki Jishin'' || {{coord|46|28.8|N|154|04.48|E|type:event}} || The earthquake happened at 1:23 p.m. [[Japan Standard Time|JST]] (04:23 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]) and resulted in a [[tsunami]] warning but did not cause significant damage.{{cite web|url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/jan2007/2007-01-12-06.asp|title=Giant Earthquake Jolts Japan, But Tsunami Warnings Cancelled|last=staff|website=www.ens-newswire.com}} The epicentre was located 95 km to the south east of the [[2006 Kuril Islands earthquake]] that struck a few weeks earlier. |- | {{dts|2007|03|25}} || 6.9 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000001}}1 ||[[2007 Noto earthquake]] || 能登半島地震 || ''Noto Hantō Jishin'' || Ishikawa Prefectureabout {{convert|11|km|mi|abbr=on}} due west of the southern end of the town of [[Wajima, Ishikawa|Wajima]] || At 9:42 a.m., a [[Richter magnitude scale|magnitude]] 6.9 [[earthquake]], struck the [[Hokuriku region]] of Japan, near the [[Noto Peninsula]]. The earthquake shook the city of [[Nanao, Ishikawa|Nanao]] and the town of [[Anamizu, Ishikawa|Anamizu]] with a [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|seismic intensity]] of 6+ on Japan's [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|''shindo'' scale]]. One death, in the city of [[Wajima, Ishikawa|Wajima]], and at least 214 injuries have been reported. A [[tsunami]] advisory was immediately made for the [[Kaga, Ishikawa|Kaga]] coast and Noto coast, and a 10–20 cm wave hit shore about 30 minutes later.{{cite web|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20070326a1.html|title=Hokuriku quake kills one, injures 170|publisher=[[The Japan Times]]|date=2007-03-26}} |- | {{dts|2007|07|16}} || 6.6 ''Mw'' ||{{Hs|000011}}11 ||[[2007 Chūetsu offshore earthquake]] || 新潟県中越沖地震 || ''Niigata-ken Chūetsu Oki Jishin'' || Niigata Prefectureabout {{convert|29|km|mi|abbr=on}} west of [[Niigata, Niigata|Niigata]] || The earthquake{{cite web| url = http://www.jma.go.jp/jma/press/0707/16b/kaisetsu200707161450.pdf| title = 2007 年７月16 日10 時13 分ころ新潟県上中越沖で発生した地震について| publisher = [[Japan Meteorological Agency]]| date = 2007-07-16| accessdate = 2007-07-19| language=Japanese}}) was a powerful [[Richter magnitude scale|magnitude]] 6.6 [[earthquake]]{{cite web|title=Powerful earthquake strikes Niigata, causes leak at nuclear power plant|url=http://www.japannewsreview.com/society/chubu/20070716page_id=754|publisher=Japan News Review|date=2007-07-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317143212/http://www.japannewsreview.com/society/chubu/20070716page_id=754|archivedate=2011-03-17|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0716/TKY200707160041.html|title=asahi.com：新潟、長野で震度６強 ８人死亡、９０８人がけが - 社会|publisher=}} that occurred 10:13 a.m. [[Japan Standard Time|local time]] (01:13 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]) on July 16, 2007, in the northwest [[Niigata Prefecture|Niigata region]] of Japan. The earthquake shook Niigata and neighbouring prefectures. The city of [[Kashiwazaki, Niigata|Kashiwazaki]] and the villages of [[Iizuna, Nagano|Iizuna]] and [[Kariwa, Niigata|Kariwa]] registered the highest [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|seismic intensity]] of a strength 6 on Japan's [[Japan Meteorological Agency seismic intensity scale|''shindo'' scale]], but the quake was felt as far away as Tokyo. Eleven deaths and at least 1,000 injuries have been reported, and 342 buildings were completely destroyed, mostly older wooden structures.[http://www.japannewsreview.com/society/chubu/20070723page_id=964 Niigata earthquake death toll rises to eleven] (''Higashi Nihon Dai-Shinsai'') || {{coord|38.510|N|142.792|E}}, depth 29 km || This [[megathrust earthquake]]'s [[earthquake hypocenter|hypocenter]] was reported to be off the [[Oshika Peninsula]], the east coast of [[Tōhoku region|Tōhoku]]{{cite news| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12709598|work=[[BBC News]]|title=Tsunami hits north-eastern Japan after massive quake| date = 11 March 2011|accessdate=11 March 2011}} It was the strongest to hit Japan and one of the [[Largest earthquakes#Largest earthquakes by magnitude|top five largest earthquakes in the world]] since seismological record-keeping began.{{cite web|url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/recenteqsww/Quakes/usc0001xgp.php |title=Magnitude 8.9 – Near the East coast of Honshu, Japan 2011 March 11 05:46:23 UTC |publisher=[[United States Geological Survey]] (USGS) |accessdate=11 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110312174548/http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/recenteqsww/Quakes/usc0001xgp.php |archivedate=12 March 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|url= http://www.theworldreporter.com/2011/03/89-earthquake-in-japan-tsunami-warning.html|title = 8.9 Earthquake in Japan, Tsunami Warning to Russia, Taiwan and South East Asia|accessdate=11 March 2011|date=11 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Japan-quake---7th-largest-in-recorded-history/tabid/417/articleID/201998/Default.aspx|title=Japan quake – 7th largest in recorded history|accessdate=11 March 2011|date=11 March 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002513/http://www.3news.co.nz/Japan-quake---7th-largest-in-recorded-history/tabid/417/articleID/201998/Default.aspx|archive-date=2011-03-16|dead-url=yes|df=}} It was followed by a [[tsunami]] with waves of up to {{convert|10|m|abbr=on}}. The disaster left thousands dead and inflicted extensive material damage to buildings and infrastructure that led to [[2011 Japanese nuclear accidents|significant accidents at four major nuclear power stations]]. |- | {{dts|2011|03|11}}

Schiff |year =2010 |title =Kashiwazaki, Japan, Earthquake of July 16, 2007 |url =https://books.google.com/books?id=JHuLExwqOsEC |publisher= American Society of Civil Engineers|isbn= 978-0-7844-1062-2}} ==External links== {{Wikinews|Quake measuring 6.9 off Japan's Honshū coast}} {{Wikinews|2011 Sendai Earthquake}} *''[http://www.bousai.go.jp/1info/pdf/saigaipamphlet_je.pdf Disaster Preparedness in Japan]'' (bilingual booklet, 3-2015 PDF from Government of Japan [http://www.cao.go.jp/en/disaster.html Cabinet Office, Director General for Disaster Management]) *[http://www.tableausoftware.com/public/gallery/japan-quakes-1900 Earthquakes in Japan Since 1900 | Tableau Public] *[http://dil-db.bosai.go.jp/saigai/ Japanese disasters interactive map] from 416 CE to 2013 (labels in Japanese) *[http://www.tableausoftware.com/public/gallery/earthquakes-week One Week of Japanese Earthquakes | Tableau Public] *{{commonscat-inline|Earthquakes in Japan}} {{external media |align=right | image1 =[http://static2.businessinsider.com/image/4d7a0d2649e2ae5e5a0e0000/japan-map.jpg Statistical map of location, size and depth of earthquakes near Japan] }} {{Earthquakes in Japan}} {{Asia topic|List of earthquakes in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Earthquakes In Japan}} [[Category:Earthquakes in Japan|*]] [[Category:Lists of earthquakes by country|Japan]] [[Category:Lists of events in Japan|Earthquakes]] [[Category:Tsunamis in Japan]]

This is a list of the fulmarine petrels, one of four types of [[Procellariidae]].
==''Macronectes''== * ''Macronectes halli'', [[northern giant petrel]], located in the southern oceans, north of the [[Antarctic convergence]] * ''Macronectes giganteus'', [[southern giant petrel]], located in the southern oceans, and southern [[polar region]] south to the [[pack ice]]
==''Fulmarus''== * ''Fulmarus glacialis'', [[northern fulmar]], breeds in the [[North Atlantic]], along the coast of eastern [[Siberia]], and the [[Alaskan Peninsula]]. Ranges through the North Atlantic Ocean and the [[North Pacific Ocean]], ** ''Fulmarus glacialis glacialis'' breeds in the high Arctic region of the [[North Atlantic]] ** ''Fulmarus glacialis auduboni'' breeds in the low Arctic and [[boreal ecosystem|boreal]] Arctic of the North Atlantic ** ''Fulmarus glacialis rodgersii'' breeds along the coast of eastern [[Siberia]] and the Alaskan Peninsula * ''Fulmarus glacialoides'', [[southern fulmar]], located in the southern [[polar region]]; [[South Atlantic Ocean]] and the [[South Pacific Ocean]]
==''Thalassoica''== * ''Thalassoica antarctica'', [[Antarctic petrel]], breeds along the [[Antarctic]] coast and on the Antarctic islands. Ranges through the southern polar region
==''Daption''== * ''Daption capense'', [[Cape petrel]], breeds on the circumpolar and New Zealand subantarctic islands, ranges throughout the southern polar region, and coastal waters off the west coast of South America ** ''Daption capense capense'' breeds on the circumpolar [[subantarctic]] islands, ranges throughout the southern oceans ** ''Daption capense australe'' breeds on the New Zealand subantarctic islands, ranges throughout the southern oceans
==''Pagodroma''== * ''Pagodroma nivea'', [[snow petrel]], located in the southern polar region ** ''Pagodroma nivea nivea'', breeds on the [[South Georgia Islands]] and adjacent islands, [[Scotia Arc]], and the Antarctic Peninsula ** ''Pagodroma nivea confusa'', breeds on the [[South Sandwich Islands]] and the [[Géologie Archipelago]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fulmarine petrels}} [[Category:Lists of birds]] [[Category:Procellariidae]] [[Category:Lists of animal species|Fulmarine petrels]]
{{Procellariiformes-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Main|States of matter}} Classically, states of matter are distinguished by changes in the properties of matter related to external factors such as [[pressure]] and [[temperature]]. States are usually distinguished by a discontinuity in one of those properties: for example, raising the temperature of ice produces a clear discontinuity at 0°C as energy goes into [[phase transition]], instead of temperature increase. The classical states of matter are usually summarised as: [[solid]], [[liquid]], [[gas]], and [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]]. In the 20th century, increased understanding of the more exotic properties of matter resulted in the identification of many additional states of matter, none of which are observed in [[Standard conditions for temperature and pressure|normal conditions]].
==Low-energy states== ===Classical states=== * '''[[Solid]]''': A solid holds a definite shape and volume without a container. The particles are held very close to each other ** '''[[Amorphous solid]]''': A solid in which there is no far-range order of the positions of the atoms. ** '''[[Crystal|Crystalline solid]]''': A solid in which atoms, molecules, or ions are packed in a regular order. ** '''[[Plastic crystal]]''': A molecular solid with long-range positional order but with constituent molecules retaining rotational freedom. ** '''[[Quasi-crystal]]''': A solid in which the positions of the atoms have long-range order, but is not in a repeating pattern. * '''[[Liquid]]''': A mostly non-compressible [[fluid]]. Able to conform to the shape of its container but retaining a (nearly) constant volume independent of pressure. ** '''[[Liquid crystal]]''': Properties intermediate between liquids and crystals. Generally, able to flow like a liquid but exhibiting long-range order. ** '''[[Disordered Hyperuniformity|Disordered hyperuniformity]]''': A state similar to a liquid and a crystal in properties. Like a crystal, its particles over large distances exhibit uniform density and are unable to compress. Like a liquid, its particles at smaller distances display the same physical properties in all directions. * '''[[Gas]]''': A compressible fluid. Not only will a gas conform to the shape of its container but it will also expand to fill the container. * '''[[Plasma (physics)|Plasma]]''': Free charged particles, usually in equal numbers, such as ions and electrons. Unlike gases, plasmas may self-generate magnetic fields and electric currents, and respond strongly and collectively to electromagnetic forces.
===Modern states=== *'''[[Excitonium]]''' *'''[[Degenerate matter]]''': matter under very high pressure, supported by the [[Pauli exclusion principle]]. **'''[[Electron-degenerate matter]]''': found inside [[white dwarf]] stars. Electrons remain bound to atoms but are able to transfer to adjacent atoms. **'''[[Neutron-degenerate matter]]''': found in [[neutron star]]s. Vast gravitational pressure compresses atoms so strongly that the electrons are forced to combine with protons via inverse beta-decay, resulting in a superdense conglomeration of neutrons. (Normally [[Neutron|free neutrons]] outside an atomic nucleus will [[Radioactive decay|decay]] with a half life of just under 15 minutes, but in a neutron star, as in the nucleus of an atom, other effects stabilize the neutrons.) **'''[[Strange matter]]''': A type of [[quark matter]] that may exist inside some neutron stars close to the [[Tolman–Oppenheimer–Volkoff limit]] (approximately 2–3 [[solar mass]]es). May be stable at lower energy states once formed. *'''[[Photonic matter]]''': Inside a quantum nonlinear medium, photons can behave as if they had mass, and can interact with each other, forming photonic "molecules". *'''[[Quantum]]''': A state that gives rise to quantized [[Hall voltage]] measured in the direction perpendicular to the current flow. **'''[[Quantum spin Hall effect|Quantum spin Hall state]]''': a theoretical phase that may pave the way for the development of electronic devices that dissipate less energy and generate less heat. This is a derivation of the quantum Hall state of matter. *'''[[Bose–Einstein condensate]]''': a phase in which a large number of [[boson]]s all inhabit the same [[quantum state]], in effect becoming one single wave/particle. This is a low energy phase that can only be formed in laboratory conditions and in very cold temperatures. It must be close to zero Kelvin, or absolute zero. [[Satyendra Bose]] and [[Albert Einstein]] predicted the existence of such a state in the 1920s, but it was not observed until 1995 by [[Eric Cornell]] and [[Carl Wieman]]. *'''[[Fermionic condensate]]''': Similar to the Bose–Einstein condensate but composed of [[fermion]]s, also known as Fermi-Dirac condensate. The [[Pauli exclusion principle]] prevents fermions from entering the same quantum state, but a pair of fermions can behave as a boson, and multiple such pairs can then enter the same quantum state without restriction. *'''[[Superconductivity]]''': is a phenomenon of exactly zero [[Electrical resistance and conductance|electrical resistance]] and expulsion of [[magnetic field]]s occurring in certain materials when [[:wikt:cooling|cooled]] below a characteristic [[Phase transition|critical temperature]]. Superconductivity is the ground state of many elemental metals. *'''[[Superfluid]]''': A phase achieved by a few [[cryogenics|cryogenic]] liquids at extreme temperature where they become able to flow without [[friction]]. A superfluid can flow up the side of an open container and down the outside. Placing a superfluid in a spinning container will result in [[quantum vortex|quantized vortices]]. *'''[[Supersolid]]''': similar to a superfluid, a supersolid is able to move without friction but retains a rigid shape. *'''[[Quantum spin liquid]]''': A disordered state in a system of interacting quantum spins which preserves its disorder to very low temperatures, unlike other disordered states. *'''[[Heavy fermion material]]s''': [[Heavy fermion material]]s or strongly correlated Fermi systems form a new state of matter that defines by [[quantum phase transition]]s, and exhibits a universal [[scale invariance|scaling]] behavior of its [[thermodynamic]], [[Transport phenomena|transport]] and [[relaxation (physics)|relaxation]] properties. [[Quantum spin liquid]], [[quasicrystal]]s, 2D [[Fermi liquid]]s, [[heavy-fermion]] metals and [[heavy-fermion superconductor]]s can belong to the new state of matter. *'''[[String-net liquid]]''': Atoms in this state have apparently unstable arrangement, like a liquid, but are still consistent in overall pattern, like a solid. *'''[[Supercritical fluid]]''': At sufficiently high temperatures and pressures the distinction between liquid and gas disappears. *'''[[Dropleton]]''': An artificial [[quasiparticle]], constituting a collection of electrons and places without them inside a semiconductor. Dropleton is the first known quasiparticle that behaves like a liquid. *'''[[Jahn–Teller effect|Jahn–Teller metal]]''': A solid that exhibits many of the characteristics of an insulator, but acts as a conductor due to a distorted crystalline structure. (The experiment was not reproduced and confirmed by other scientists.) *'''[[Time crystals]]''': A state of matter where an object can have movement even at their lowest energy state. *[[Rydberg polaron|'''Rydberg polaron''']]: A state of matter that can only exist at ultra-cool temperatures and consists of atoms inside of atoms.
==Very high energy states== *'''[[Quark–gluon plasma]]''': A phase in which [[quark]]s become free and able to move independently (rather than being perpetually bound into particles, or bound to each other in a quantum lock where exerting force adds energy and eventually solidifies into another quark) in a sea of [[gluon]]s (subatomic particles that transmit the [[strong interaction|strong force]] that binds quarks together). May be briefly attainable in [[particle accelerator]]s. **'''[[Weakly symmetric matter]]''': for up to 10<sup>−12</sup> seconds after the Big Bang the strong, weak and electromagnetic forces were unified. **'''[[Strongly symmetric matter]]''': for up to 10<sup>−36</sup> seconds after the [[Big Bang]], the energy density of the universe was so high that the [[fundamental interaction|four forces of nature]] — [[strong interaction|strong]], [[weak interaction|weak]], [[electromagnetism|electromagnetic]], and [[gravitation]]al — are thought to have been unified into one single force. As the universe expanded, the temperature and density dropped and the gravitational force separated, which is a process called [[symmetry breaking]].
{{State of matter}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:States Of Matter}} [[Category:Physics-related lists]] [[Category:Phases of matter|+]]
[[fr:Liste des états de la matière]] [[it:Stati della materia]] [[th:รายชื่อสถานะของสสาร]]
